contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Kaula-island-P1010936a.JPG|thumb|300px|Ka{{okina}}ula Island viewed from the north]] :''For the islet in the United States Minor Outlying Islands, see [[Palmyra Atoll]] '''Ka{{okina}}ula''' Island, also called Ka{{okina}}ula Rock, is a small, crescent-shaped offshore islet in the [[Hawaiian Islands]]. ==Geography== It is located {{convert|23|mi|km}} west-southwest of Kawaihoa Point on [[Niihau|Ni{{okina}}ihau]], and about {{convert|150|nmi|km}} west of [[Honolulu]]. The island is actually the very top of a volcanic [[tuff cone]] that rests on top of a larger, submerged [[shield volcano]]. At its highest point, the island reaches a height of {{convert|548|ft|m}}.<ref>[http://www.volcanolive.com/kaula.html Kaula Volcano] John Seach, Volcano Live</ref> The ocean has carved large sea cliffs on the sides of the island. There is a large cave on the northwest side of the island called [[Kahalauaola]] (Shark Cave).<ref>[http://atsea.nmfs.hawaii.edu/islands/kaula.htm Ka{{okina}}ula Island] NOAA Ship Townsend Cromwell, Student Connection</ref> The [[United States Census Bureau]] defines Ka{{okina}}ula as [[census tract|Census Tract]] 411 of [[Kauai County, Hawaii|Kaua{{okina}}i County, Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The [[United States Census, 2000|2000 census]] showed that the uninhabited island had a land area of {{convert|158.2|acre|km2 sqmi}}.<ref>[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-show_geoid=Y&-tree_id=4001&-_showChild=Y&-context=dt&-errMsg=&-all_geo_types=N&-mt_name=DEC_2000_SF1_U_P001&-redoLog=false&-transpose=N&-search_map_config=|b=50|l=en|t=4001|zf=0.0|ms=sel_00dec|dw=0.32574415146711605|dh=0.22784596312794334|dt=gov.census.aff.domain.map.EnglishMapExtent|if=gif|cx=-160.54887078557877|cy=21.657999272138042|zl=5|pz=5|bo=318:317:316:314:313:323:319|bl=362:393:358:357:356:355:354|ft=350:349:335:389:388:332:331|fl=381:403:204:380:369:379:368|g=01000US&-PANEL_ID=p_dt_geo_map&-_lang=en&-geo_id=14000US15007041100&-CONTEXT=dt&-format=&-search_results=01000US&-ds_name=DEC_2000_SF1_U Census Tract 411, Kaua{{okina}}i County] United States Census Bureau</ref> Because of [[erosion]], the island is slowly shrinking. Kaʻula, which he spelled as "Tahoora", was one of the first five islands sighted by Captain James Cook in 1778. ==Lighthouse== A [[lighthouse]] was completed on the island in 1932 by the former [[United States Lighthouse Service]]. It remained in operation through 1947. ==Military use== The island has been used as a [[bombing range]] by the [[United States Navy]] since at least 1952. Inert ordnance is currently used, although live explosive ordnance has been used in the past. There is a risk of [[unexploded ordnance]] on the island. Permission from the U.S. Navy is required to land on the island. In 1978, over the objection of the U.S. Navy, the state of Hawai{{okina}}i claimed ownership of Ka{{okina}}ula and named the island a State Seabird Sanctuary. A final determination of ownership has not yet been made, and the Navy still uses the southeast point of the island as an aerial bombing and strafing target.<ref>[http://www.nauticalcharts.noaa.gov/nsd/coastpilot/files/cp7/CP7-42ed-Ch14_7.pdf U.S. Coast Pilot 7, Chapter 14, p. 634]</ref> ==Diving== Ka{{okina}}ula is uninhabited but fishermen and [[Scuba diving|scuba divers]] frequently visit the island. Five Fathom Pinnacle, {{convert|3|mi|km}} west-northwest of Ka{{okina}}ula, is also a noted dive spot.<ref>[http://www.xpda.com/nwhi/5fathomPinnacle Underwater Photos from Five Fathom Pinnacle]</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{Cite book | last1 = Tabrah | first1 = Ruth M. | title = Ni{{okina}}ihau, the last Hawaiian island | publisher = Press Pacifica | year = 1987 | isbn = 0-916630-59-5 }} *{{Cite book | last1 = Tava | first1 = Rerioterai | last2 = Keale | first2 = Moses K. | title = Niihau, the traditions of a Hawaiian island | publisher = Mutual Publishing | year = 1998 | url = http://www.mutualpublishing.com/bookinfo.aspx?bookID=242 | isbn = 0-935180-80-X }} ==External links== *[http://www.hawaiioirc.org/OIRC-ISLETS-Niihau/OIRC-ISLETS-Niihau-Kaula.htm Offshore Islet Restoration Committee, Kaula] *[http://www.janeresture.com/kaula/ Ka{{okina}}ula Island] *[http://xpda.com/nauticalcharts/19380%20OAHU%20TO%20NIIHAU.png Nautical Chart Containing Ka{{okina}}ula Island] *[http://www.xpda.com/hawaii/kaularock/ Kaula Rock Photos] Photographs of Ka{{okina}}ula Island, May 2008 {{Kauai County, Hawaii}} {{Hawaiian volcanism}} {{coord|21|39|17|N|160|32|29|W|source:eswiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kaula}} [[Category:Geography of Kauai County, Hawaii]] [[Category:Niihau]] [[Category:Tuff cones]] [[Category:Uninhabited islands of Hawaii]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Hawaii]]
